item.title: Jazz lives on across the province
item.description:
While the Festival may have ended for another year, jazz lives on in other parts of the province. From east to west, north to south, jazz festivals are a staple in Ontario and can be found in practically every corner. 


Here's a few to add to your checklist this summer and fall:

TD Downtown Oakville Jazz Festival Aug 8 - Aug 9
Prince Edward County Jazz Festival Aug 12 - Aug 17
TD Markham Jazz Festival Aug 14 - Aug 17
Niagara Jazz Festival Aug 22 - Aug 24
Guelph Jazz Festival Sept 3 - Sept 7
Southside Shuffle Sept 5 - Sept 7
All Canadian Jazz Festival Sept 5 - Sept 7
Brantford International Jazz Festival Sept 12 - Sept 14
Steelcity Jazz Festival Oct 16 - Oct 26
Orillia Jazz Festival Oct 17 - Oct  19

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Brian Blain

item.title: Now Accepting Submissions
item.description:
Calling all Artists! The 2014 TD Toronto Jazz Festival has come to an end and we are now preparing for 2015! Submissions are being accepted and can be done electronically or by mail.

The submission deadline is December 15th, and October 15th 2014 for those applying for the Canada Council tour funds.

For specific details about submissions please click here. Good luck!

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Brian Blain

item.title: Photo Recap
item.description:
If a picture is worth a 1000 words, then a video should be worth a million! Check our Instagram recap for some of our favourite Festival highlights. Tweet or share with us on Facebook some of your memories. You just might win some CDs for your contribution.




Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Brian Blain

item.title: A Special Offer
item.description:
From our friends at Cirque Du Soleil, a special offer to enjoy their latest production under the big top when it opens later this month.

Step into the curio cabinet of an ambitious inventor who defies the laws of time, space and dimension in order to reinvent everything around him. Suddenly, the visible becomes invisible, perspectives are transformed, and the world is literally turned upside down in a place that's as beautiful as it is mysterious.

Kurios - Cabinet of Curiosities is an ingenious blend of unusual curiosity acts and stunning acrobatic prowess from Cirque du Soleil. Let KURIOS show you that anything is possible through the power of imagination.

Click here for more information and to purchase tickets. No promo code needed. 

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Brian Blain

item.title: Yanis Khamsi's interview with John Scofield
item.description:
In his first-ever artist interview, TDJ News Corps member Yanis Khamsi chats on the phone with John Scofield. They cover off a variety of topics - from the Uberjam band to music on the internet to the state of music in general. Hear the interview.

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Josh Grossman

item.title: Yanis Khamsi's review of Robert Randoph and Kenny Wayne Shepherd
item.description:
The band certainly had the freedom of the 1960's and 1970's. Not only did the band members switch instruments numerous times, but at one point Randolph invited anybody in the audience capable of playing guitar on stage to jam!

Read the full review...

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Josh Grossman

item.title: Benjamin Thomas' review of PRISM and Uberjam
item.description:
Thursday was made for jazz...Indeed, it was a very special night in Toronto jazz: legendary bassist Dave Holland’s PRISM and renowned guitarist John Scofield’s Überjam were about to take the stage for a grand co-headlining event.

Read the full review.

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Josh Grossman

item.title: Benjamin Thomas' review of Dirty Dozen/Lettuce
item.description:
The Dirty Dozen formed 37 years ago in the hopes of preserving classic New Orleans jazz. However, their time together has been an iterative process. Over the years, the band developed a sound frontman Gregory Davis compares to gumbo (a traditional southern dish combining various flavours and spices). After a brief dismissal of the rain, Davis and his bandmates got the ball rolling with an energetic dance number that inspired the crowd to stand up and clap along...

Read the full review...

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Josh Grossman

item.title: Yanis Khamsi's review of Melissa Etheridge (and more)
item.description:
This was no ordinary jazz concert. Thousands gathered in Nathan Phillips Square to kick off World Pride. Premier Kathleen Wynne made a surprise appearance to anoint the festival, promising to make Ontario the most accepting place on earth for the LGBTQ community...

Read the full review.

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Josh Grossman

item.title: Benjamin Thomas' review of Hiromi
item.description:
There’s a child within all of us—a spirit that comes alive when we do things like, say, skipping out on work to catch a show at the jazz festival. Pianist Hiromi Uehara, who is known to her fans as simply Hiromi, channelled that same childlike spirit Tuesday night.

Read the full review...

Category: 
TDJ News
item.dc:creator: Josh Grossman
